Definition: Dead, usually if multiple individuals die

Expression: Wearing a pine overcoat (i.e. a wooden coffin)
Remarks: Idiom used by American gangsters of the early 20th century.

Definition: To die, usually before doing some sort of important task

Remarks: An alternative of 'turn one's toes up to the daisies' (See 'push up daisies' above.)
A skeleton with a scythe, often in a cloak
This is "T.U." in the ICAO spelling alphabet, an abbreviation for Tits Up.

Expression: Take the last train to glory.
Remarks: Comes from the Christian belief that a heaven or greater life exists after death for the faithful.
To take one's own life means to commit suicide.
Gangster

Definition: To be killed by an illness
Remarks: Usually passive
Used in the movie The Late Show (1977): "I'm always sorry to hear any of God's creatures stepping off." (Spoken by the character Ron Birdwell, played by Eugene Roche.)
As in 'like a candle'
British

Definition: Murdered, then disposed of in water.
Remarks: Popularized by The Godfather
Six feet is the traditional depth of a grave
Quoted from Shakespeare's Hamlet. Sometimes used as 'this mortal coil' to refer to the fact that one is alive in a troublesome way.[2]
From the poem, "Invictus," by William Ernest Henley: "Beyond this place of wrath and tears, Looms but the horror of the shade."
Usually referring to the death of a pet, especially if the owners are parents of young children i.e. "The dog was sent to a farm."

Expression: Send one to Eternity or to the Promised Land

Remarks: In the Biblical passage Revelation 6:8, a pale horse is ridden by Death, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. The expression "behold a pale horse" has been used as the title of a 1964 film by Fred Zinnemann and a 1991 book by ufologist William Milton Cooper.
Usually referring to the death of a pet, i.e. "Crossing the Rainbow Bridge."
Usually referring to the unnatural death of a pet

Definition: To have died and be under the ground
Remarks: This idiom dates back to the early 20th century. Also 'under the daisies' and 'turn one's toes up to the daisies, which date back to the mid 19th century. See 'to turn up one's toes' below.
Salvation Army terminology.

British. In English slang, the word "pop" means the same as "pawn." A 19th century working man who is mortally ill or at the point of death might apocryphally tell his family to take his clothes to the pawn shop to pay for his funeral; especially his clogs which would be his most expensive/valuable items. Sometimes used in the third person, "they've popped his clogs."
British. Also means 'to stop working'

Definition: To die because of something one has done
Remarks: Often applied to a moral reason, similar to "To make the ultimate sacrifice"
Australian
Also 'to pass on'

Definition: One thinks he's going to die

Remarks: British. Not to be confused with 'off the hook' (no longer in trouble).
This means to die. Viking expression, back into fashion nowadays

Definition: Will die soon; have little time left to live
Remarks: Also not be long for this world
From the poem by Dylan Thomas, "Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night."
From 1993 film Demolition Man
Comes from the Christian belief that a soul needs to see God, its 'maker', after his life for judgment.

Definition: To die while fighting for a cause
Remarks: Also 'make the supreme sacrifice'

Definition: To die in an accident or violent event

Remarks: Usually referring to the death of a pet, especially if the owners are parents with children, i.e. "The dog went to live on a farm."
British. Popular in films. Also "Kiss your ass goodbye" (U.S.).
Also can refer to death itself in that death is the scariest of all terrors.

Definition: Death of a military person due to enemy action.
Context: Military language, official and informal use.
Remarks: Official military language brought to public attention by widespread use in media during the Vietnam War and later books and films on that war. Term continues to be used in connection with military deaths due to enemy activity.
Polish saying. 'Calendar' implies somebody's time of death (kicking at particular moment of time)

One theory says that it comes from a method of suicide of the Middle Ages in which one stands on a bucket with a noose tied around their neck. Once they kick the bucket, they are hanged.[13] Another theory is the kind of beam from which a pig is suspended, which is also called a 'bucket' in the Norfolk dialect.[2] Also 'kick off' (American).[1]
aka Capital Punishment, Death Penalty
First used by Edward Young, but the phrase 'the majority' is extremely old.
From an 1867 poem by George Eliot
From the Holy Bible, Luke 16:22.

British. Also 'to hop the stick'. Also means 'to depart suddenly'. A stick is placed on the ground. Pagan beliefs say that to 'hop the stick', i.e. you stand on one side of the stick and jump to the other side, places you in the afterworld.
"Rattler" is a slang expression for a freight train.

Expression: Have one foot in the grave
Definition: To be close to death because of illness or age

Remarks: See Seppuku. Often misspelt as Hari-kari.
A dinner pail is a bucket in which a workman used to carry his dinner. See 'kick the bucket' below.
Refers to the sun setting at the west.

Expression: Go to, or head for, the last roundup
Remarks: Associated with dying cowboys, along with "Going to that big ranch in the sky."

Definition: To die and go to heaven
Remarks: 'Location' is a fancied venue in the afterlife that parallels an earthly venue associated with the deceased, such as "Big ranch in the sky".[10]
The death is referred to as a watery grave.
This phrase comes from the idea that people get their just desserts after they die.

Definition: To drown or otherwise die at sea
Remarks: Peregrine Pickle describes Davy Jones as 'the fiend that presides over all the evil sprits of the deep'.
Reference to going to heaven, which is perceived to be better than Earth.

Expression: Go the way of all flesh
Remarks: Also means to come to an end. In the Authorized King James Version of the bible 'all flesh' means 'all humans and animals'.

Expression: Go out with one's boots on/with a bang/in style
Definition: To die while doing something enjoyed
To be shipped to one's birthplace, dead
Remarks: Often exaggerated
British. From WWII (Gone for a Burton).
Australian. Also means 'to fail' or 'to go bankrupt'.

Definition: Usually refers to the death of a horse

Remarks: Also means 'to stop working' or 'to give up hope'. The Old English meaning of the word 'ghost' is preserved in this idiom.

Definition: To completely exterminate all of a kind of something
Remarks: All of it is gone

Definition: The act of killing your own brother or sister

Remarks: Also 'worm food'

Definition: To be thinner and weaker and close to death.
Remarks: Also 'to be fading fast' or 'sinking fast'

Definition: When a species as a whole ceases to exist

Remarks: Spoken by Daleks (from Doctor Who) when under orders to kill
As slang, 'to euthanize'
This expression could also mean that they're simply just ill and not necessarily dying.
'Just drop dead' is a rude way of telling someone to get lost.
Also means 'to be in a bad situation of which one cannot get out'.[2]

Definition: To die while able, or during activity, as opposed to in infirmity or while asleep.
Remarks: Old West usage: To die in a gunfight, as with the film They Died with Their Boots On. Also connotes dying in combat.
Usually refers to the unnatural death of a pet
A death that could have been avoided with due diligence
Charles Dickens used this phrase at the beginning of A Christmas Carol.

The term 'dodo' originally comes from the Portuguese word doudo, meaning simpleton. It was applied to the extinct bird because their supposed lack of intelligence led to their extinction. Therefore, it has been used as an old-fashioned or stupid person since 19th century.[2] Also 'dead as the dodo'.
The final curtain indicates the end of the play - hence the term became synonymous with death.
The departed one has entered the Promised Land (i.e. Heaven)
Also means to die.

Definition: To die in a way that is considered unpleasant
Remarks: British. Also 'to meet a sticky end'.
Crosses the rivers Styx and Acheron which divide the world of the living from the world of the dead
This idiom refers to the counters in gambling called 'chips', which are exchanged for cash at the end of the game.
Say 'Candyman' 5 times while looking in a mirror, and the Candyman appears and kills you with his hooked right hand.
A farm owner who had life insurance would effectively, upon dying, 'buy the farm'.
Cockney rhyming slang for 'dead'.

Definition: To shoot someone in the head

Remarks: Also means 'failed'
North American.
Originally used to refer to the 'veil' that hides the inmost sanctuary of the Temple in Jerusalem. Sometimes refers to just a mysterious place.
The preposition 'from' is often added before the phrase.
The position of fish when dead.

Used frequently by talk radio host Rush Limbaugh on The Rush Limbaugh Show, generally when a dictator or an avowed enemy of the United States has died. Originally used in his first book, The Way Things Ought to Be. See also Jargon of The Rush Limbaugh Show.
